messages.text:
A question about (noisy) stochastic reaction networks:
The rule x -> x + x does provides a triggerable (just add one x) exponential growth, however it can't be used in stochastics systems, as random fluctuations  in concentration would likely trigger exponential growth at an unwanted moment.
Does someone know a reaction network that is robust to noise in concentration of all of it's components and stable but some particular input(change in concentration of one or more components) triggers exponential (or logistic) growth in one component?
I know that some mechanism like that exists in biology.
I don't think you can control the noise of all concentrations, but if you relax that to some

elements.text: I don't think you can control the noise of all concentrations, but if you relax that to some

messages.text: <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2589004218300348#:~:text=Mean%2Dindependent%20noise%20control%20allows,noise%20without%20shifting%20boundary%20locations|https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2589004218300348#:~:text=Mean%2Dindependent%20noise%20c[…]thout%20shifting%20boundary%20locations>

attachments.title: Mean-Independent Noise Control of Cell Fates via Intermediate States

messages.text:
I really have no idea about the domain or what would make it useful for Catalyst users. I just thought through what would be necessary to use DiffEq + Optimization to design such a chemical switch and realized that nature imposes such constraints.
In my case the energy of each component would be a degree of freedom, so i only care that the mechanism is feasible not that it uses particular chemicals.
So i don't feel comfortable to make proposals how to do implement this.
I will open an issue but it would be great if a domain expert contributes.

elements.text: open an issue

messages.text: Hi, can you guys recommend any conferences/attached workshops that would be good targets for smaller SciML publications? I'm struggling a bit figuring this out since all the Karniadakis PINN stuff usually went into JCOMP and most "application papers" are residing in domain-specific journals/conferences. I'm working on a PINN edge case which is most probably not general/novel enough for the big ML conferences like ICML etc...

messages.text:
Hi, I didn’t find anything built-in DifferentialEquations to draw the vector-field of a 2D system, so I though of using `quiver`. For that, I wanted to separate the right-hand-side of the system from the function used to create the `ODEProblem` . So I did the following, but it is not working. What am I missing?

``````julia
function rhs(u, params)
    x, y = u
    β = params[1]
    dx = -β*y
    dy = β*x
    return [dx, dy]
end

function dudt1!(du,u,params,t)
    du = rhs(u,params)
end```

elements.text: Hi, I didn’t find anything built-in DifferentialEquations to draw the vector-field of a 2D system, so I though of using
quiver
. For that, I wanted to separate the right-hand-side of the system from the function used to create the
ODEProblem
. So I did the following, but it is not working. What am I missing?

```julia
function rhs(u, params)
    x, y = u
    β = params[1]
    dx = -β*y
    dy = β*x
    return [dx, dy]
end

function dudt1!(du,u,params,t)
    du = rhs(u,params)
end

messages.text: you're shadowing not updating `du`

elements.text: you're shadowing not updating
du

messages.text: `du .= rhs(u,params)`

elements.text: du .= rhs(u,params)

messages.text:
Some parameter estimation problems have finite escape time solutions in their parameter space to be explored.
This problem is called optimization under unknown constraints (f.e: <https://arxiv.org/abs/1004.4027> ). Do we have some optimizers that can do that (and possible use the knowledge about how early the finte escape was)?

attachments.title: Optimization Under Unknown Constraints

messages.text:
I am trying to most efficiently solve a linear ODE (of ~100 state variables). I need to calculate its solution at many, evenly spaced timepoints. The twist is that the actual output of the model is the sum of many of the state variables (e.g. sum of the first 50 is the first observable, then the second 50 is the second observable). This gives rise to a weakly oscillatory system with overall exponential decay or growth. (This is a way to express Gamma-distributed delay equations using the <https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.07571|LCT>.)

So far, just calculating `expm(A*δt)` has been most efficient, but is by far the slowest part of my code. I've tried Krylov methods in ExponentialUtilities.jl, and using `LawsonEuler` in DiffEq.jl, which end up slower. Some matrix decomposition approach is temping—for example, I could express the sum within the eigenvectors—but <https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjI2oSEycHuAhVByaQKHfgqCqsQFjAAegQIAhAC&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cs.cornell.edu%2Fcv%2FResearchPDF%2F19ways%2B.pdf&usg=AOvVaw2rq2d6snwBYEz5ZB1HQwV1|suffer from roundoff error>. Am I missing something? It seems like this would come up when efficiently solving large linear systems as approximations of non-linear systems, like with the Koopman Op...

This gives rise to a weakly oscillatory system with overall exponential decay or growth. (This is a way to express Gamma-distributed delay equations using the

messages.text:
Hi Chris, I was working on this multiple shooting issue:
<https://github.com/SciML/DiffEqFlux.jl/issues/481>
I tried to change the `predict_neuralode` function to this:
```function predict_neuralode(u_initial, timesteps, p)
         tmp_prob = remake(prob, p=p, tspan=(timesteps[1],timesteps[length(timesteps)]), u0=u_initial)
         tmpq = Array(solve(tmp_prob, Tsit5(), saveat=timesteps))
         return tmpq
end```
but it doesn't work and I am always getting stuck in a local minima. Do you have any suggestions?

elements.text: Hi Chris, I was working on this multiple shooting issue:
I tried to change the
predict_neuralode
function to this:

function predict_neuralode(u_initial, timesteps, p)
         tmp_prob = remake(prob, p=p, tspan=(timesteps[1],timesteps[length(timesteps)]), u0=u_initial)
         tmpq = Array(solve(tmp_prob, Tsit5(), saveat=timesteps))
         return tmpq
end
but it doesn't work and I am always getting stuck in a local minima. Do you have any suggestions?

messages.text: Hellohello. Are there any implementations of distributions with the reparameterization trick built-in? E.g. in PyTorch you can do `Normal(foo).rsample()`, and backpropagate through this. I presumed that Flux and Turing might play nicely together in this regard, but I couldn't find any examples of this. Thanks for any help!

One way to go around this might be use a temp variable to store the value according to the bias and then make it equal to initial_params(). Is there any other way?

messages.text: <@U01LU1QSRGW> has joined the channel

Not sure if this is the right channel to ask this. I'm writing an interpretator for a Probabilistic Programming course and I'm opting to implement it in Julia. I need to use primitive types that can be auto-differentiated. i.e. every other classmate implementing the project in python is urged to use TensorFlow for primitives to ensure auto-differentiability. With Julia, can I get away with using floats and arrays of floats or should I immediately consider employing auto-differentiability package? Note, auto-differentiability is not a requirement currently, but in a month or two I will need to be able to hook up my interpreter to an auto-differentiation package or implement it myself.

messages.text:
Hey, I have understood that some tests for static dense fail while trying to solve <https://github.com/SciML/DiffEqFlux.jl/issues/480> I have added bias as an optional feature and thus it must not be failing in the test cases where it has not been used. Can anyone suggest me any changes? On the left in this pic is changed code and on the right is the original code in DiffEqFlux. The test on which it fails is
```using OrdinaryDiffEq, StochasticDiffEq, DelayDiffEq
using Flux, Zygote, Test
using DiffEqFlux, DiffEqSensitivity

mp = Float32[0.1,0.1]
x = Float32[2.; 0.]
xs = Float32.(hcat([0.; 0.], [1.; 0.], [2.; 0.]))
tspan = (0.0f0,1.0f0)
staticdudt = FastChain(StaticDense(2,50,tanh),StaticDense(50,2))
node = NeuralODE(staticdudt,tspan,Tsit5(),save_everystep=false,save_start=false,sensealg=BacksolveAdjoint(),p=p)
grads = Zygote.gradient(()->sum(node(x)),Flux.params(x,node))  -->shows error in this line.```
The error being shown is --> DimensionMismatch("array could not be broadcast to match destination") (which somehow is coming from function StaticDense_adjoint. I have been stuck debugging and trying for few days now. Can someone correct me if I am wrong or suggest me any other experiments to try?

elements.text: Hey, I have understood that some tests for static dense fail while trying to solve

I have added bias as an optional feature and thus it must not be failing in the test cases where it has not been used. Can anyone suggest me any changes? On the left in this pic is changed code and on the right is the original code in DiffEqFlux. The test on which it fails is

using OrdinaryDiffEq, StochasticDiffEq, DelayDiffEq
using Flux, Zygote, Test
using DiffEqFlux, DiffEqSensitivity

mp = Float32[0.1,0.1]
x = Float32[2.; 0.]
xs = Float32.(hcat([0.; 0.], [1.; 0.], [2.; 0.]))
tspan = (0.0f0,1.0f0)
staticdudt = FastChain(StaticDense(2,50,tanh),StaticDense(50,2))
node = NeuralODE(staticdudt,tspan,Tsit5(),save_everystep=false,save_start=false,sensealg=BacksolveAdjoint(),p=p)
grads = Zygote.gradient(()->sum(node(x)),Flux.params(x,node))  -->shows error in this line.

The error being shown is --> DimensionMismatch("array could not be broadcast to match destination") (which somehow is coming from function StaticDense_adjoint. I have been stuck debugging and trying for few days now. Can someone correct me if I am wrong or suggest me any other experiments to try?

messages.text:
> Timeline:
> 
> *Deadline for Proposal Submission: March 5, 2021*
> Projects will be Notified: April 15, 2021 (or sooner)
> 
> Available Funding:
> 
> Up to $5,000 per proposal
> 
> Eligibility:
> 
> Any NumFOCUS Fiscally Sponsored or Affiliated project may submit 1 proposal on behalf of the project per grant cycle.
> If you wish to solicit proposal ideas from your project community, the project leaders must organize their own review process to select the proposal that the leadership will put forward to NumFOCUS.
> Funding can be used for: code development; documentation work; website updates; workshops and sprints; educational, sustainability, and diversity initiatives; or other types of projects.
> Proposed work must be achievable within the 12 months following the award.
> The call is open to applicants from any nationality and can be performed at any university, institute, or business worldwide (US export laws permitting).
> 
> Funding Distribution:
> For fiscally sponsored projects only, NumFOCUS can *deposit the grant funding directly into the project’s account*. The project would then submit invoices through the normal channels (i.e. Rocket) to pay the grant expenses.
> NumFOCUS can set up an *independent contractor agreement* with an individual or company.
> NumFOCUS can award the money as a *grant or subcontract to a student or postdoc at a university* (depending on the rules of the university).
> NumFOCUS can *directly pay for expenses* associated with the grant (e.g. booking flights on behalf of project leaders to attend a workshop, per diems for travel days)

messages.text: Yup and Catalyst.jl is built to allow for translating discrete models of agent defined by continuous-time Markov Chains

elements.text: Yup and Catalyst.jl is built to allow for translating discrete models of agent defined by continuous-time Markov Chains

messages.text: We need to allow MTK translating it to the forward Kolmogorov equations though, which isn't hard but hasn't been done yet.

elements.text: We need to allow MTK translating it to the forward Kolmogorov equations though, which isn't hard but hasn't been done yet.
